project_metadata.paper_title: FAIMS Mobile: Flexible, open-source software for field research
project_metadata.research_context: Software publication describing FAIMS Mobile, a native Android application supported by an Ubuntu server, designed for customisable field data collection across disciplines including archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile software version is 2.5 for code and 2.5.20 for executables
evidence.verbatim_quote: Current code version 2.5 ... Current software version 2.5.20

evidence.evidence_text: Software is licensed under GPLv3 open-source licence
evidence.verbatim_quote: Legal Code License GPLv3 ... Legal Software License GPLv3

evidence.evidence_text: Software uses Java, Ruby, XML, SQLite, Spatialite, Javarosa, Antlr, Puppet, Apache, Imagemagick, God, Beanshell, gson, guice, Nutiteq, NativeCSS, Protobuf, and Robotium
evidence.verbatim_quote: Software code languages, tools, and services used: Java, Ruby, XML, SQLite, Spatialite, Javarosa, Antlr, Puppet, Apache, Imagemagick, God, Beanshell, gson, guice, Nutiteq (non-free), NativeCSS, Protobuf, Robotium

evidence.evidence_text: Software requires Android 6+ and Ubuntu 16.04
evidence.verbatim_quote: Installation requirements & dependencies: Android 6+, Ubuntu 16.04

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile has been under development since 2012
evidence.verbatim_quote: It is mature software that has been under development since 2012

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Project is based at Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is open-source software developed by the Field Acquired Information Management Systems Project, an e-research infrastructure project based at Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia

evidence.evidence_text: ODK was designed for social surveys where an investigator asks questions of an interviewee
evidence.verbatim_quote: ODK was designed for social surveys, where an investigator asks questions of a interviewee

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS originated in archaeology where investigators record observations about material things and relationships
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS originated in archaeology, where an investigator records observations about things in the material world, relationships between those observations, and metadata contextualising the collection of those observations

evidence.evidence_text: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016 [8]

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS developed XML-based domain specific language (DSL) to simplify customisation
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS has developed a XML-based domain specific language (DSL) to simplify customisation. Using this DSL, a single file is used to generate a complete definition packet

evidence.evidence_text: Projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile using both detailed definition packet and DSL-based approaches
evidence.verbatim_quote: In addition to deployments conducted by the FAIMS team, projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile themselves using both the detailed approach of producing an entire definition packet and the simplified DSL-based method [20,21]

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Javarosa to render native Android UI elements at runtime
evidence.verbatim_quote: Javarosa to render native Android UI elements at runtime

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses SQLite3 for attribute-key-value datastore with runtime-definable schemas
evidence.verbatim_quote: Sqlite3 to store an attribute-key-value datastore (with data schemas definable at runtime)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses an append-only data model inspired by Google's Protobufs
evidence.verbatim_quote: An append-only data model inspired by Google's Protobufs

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Beanshell for runtime scripting via Java API
evidence.verbatim_quote: Beanshell to provide runtime scripting via calls to an underlying Java API

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses Spatialite and Nutiteq for geospatial data storage and rendering
evidence.verbatim_quote: Spatialite to encode geospatial data in the datastore; Nutiteq to render geospatial data

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS server uses Ruby on Rails/Apache stack for synchronisation, version review, and user management
evidence.verbatim_quote: A Ruby on Rails/Apache stack to provide a server for synchronisation, version review, user management, and similar tasks, which can be hosted online or on modest hardware in the field

evidence.evidence_text: Five years of deployment experience revealed the importance of quality assurance
evidence.verbatim_quote: Five years of deployment experience revealed the importance of quality assurance, something too often neglected in academic software

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests
evidence.verbatim_quote: Due to the need for significant QA per deployment, FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests on customised data collection modules, such that large amounts of test data can be automatically added via the normal user interface

evidence.evidence_text: Since first public release in 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times
evidence.verbatim_quote: Since our first public release in 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times (by our team or independently), with 29 confirmed field deployments, nine of which included multiple field seasons

evidence.evidence_text: 29 confirmed field deployments, nine with multiple field seasons
evidence.verbatim_quote: with 29 confirmed field deployments, nine of which included multiple field seasons

evidence.evidence_text: Approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 hours using the software
evidence.verbatim_quote: Considering only FAIMS-led development, approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 h employing the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research

evidence.evidence_text: Software used in archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research
evidence.verbatim_quote: employing the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research

evidence.evidence_text: First research publications based on FAIMS-generated data expected in 2018
evidence.verbatim_quote: The first research publications based on data generated using FAIMS will appear in 2018

evidence.evidence_text: 2016-2018 NSW Research Attraction and Acceleration Program award funding additional deployments
evidence.verbatim_quote: A 2016–2018 New South Wales Research Attraction and Acceleration Program award is funding deployments at additional projects, including community heritage and citizen science applications

evidence.evidence_text: An experienced developer can rapidly prototype a recording system in one to two developer-days
evidence.verbatim_quote: An experienced developer can rapidly prototype a recording system if data and workflow models are available (well-scoped systems of moderate complexity can be prototyped in one to two developer-days)

evidence.evidence_text: Case studies showed users benefited from increased fieldwork efficiency
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three case studies involving archaeological deployments [8] showed that users benefited from the increased efficiency of fieldwork

evidence.evidence_text: Time saved by avoiding digitisation offset time to implement FAIMS
evidence.verbatim_quote: The time saved by avoiding digitisation and data cleaning more than offset the time required to implement FAIMS, resulting in more data collected during fieldwork of a given duration

evidence.evidence_text: Born-digital data avoided problems with delayed digitisation
evidence.verbatim_quote: Born-digital data avoided problems with delayed digitisation, which often occurred long after field recording when the context of the record had been forgotten, or the person who made the record was no longer available

evidence.evidence_text: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data
evidence.verbatim_quote: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data

evidence.evidence_text: Information could be exchanged more quickly between excavators and specialists
evidence.verbatim_quote: They noted that information could be exchanged more quickly between excavators and specialists, which in one case improved 'post-excavation reconstruction of the site' and facilitated the evaluation of patterns for meaning in another

evidence.evidence_text: Process of moving from paper to digital required comprehensive reviews of field practice
evidence.verbatim_quote: They also observed that the process of moving from paper to digital required comprehensive reviews of field practice, during which knowledge implicit in existing systems became explicit, and data was modelled more carefully

evidence.evidence_text: Researchers gained familiarity with software demands including need for extensive testing
evidence.verbatim_quote: By participating in a 'miniature software development project', researchers gained familiarity with the strengths, limits, and demands of software, especially the need for extensive testing

evidence.evidence_text: Greatest challenge is reallocation of time from end to beginning of project
evidence.verbatim_quote: The greatest challenge posed by the transition from paper has been the reallocation of time from the end of a project (digitisation) to the beginning (data modelling, development, and testing), even if an overall time-savings is realised

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS supports embedding URIs into controlled vocabularies
evidence.verbatim_quote: URIs can be embedded in controlled vocabularies and other elements [17], connecting them to linked open data sources (e.g., species information can be linked to the Encyclopedia of Life [24])

evidence.evidence_text: Localisation can translate local language to standard vocabulary
evidence.verbatim_quote: Localisation can be used to 'translate' a local language of practice to a standard vocabulary (e.g., archaeological 'context' or 'locus' can be translated to 'statigraphic unit'—and then linked to an online ontology)

evidence.evidence_text: Customisable export can format data for existing services or standards
evidence.verbatim_quote: Customisable data export can format data for existing services or standards (e.g., archaeological records can be exported not only as shapefiles, CSVs, or a 3NF relational database for incorporation into an existing geodatabase, but also as XML or GeoJSON for ingest into domain-specific repositories like Open Context)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS core software written in Java and Ruby, customised using XML, Beanshell, and CSS files
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile consists of 'core' software written in Java and Ruby, customised to particular field deployments using reusable definition packets consisting of XML, Beanshell, and CSS files

evidence.evidence_text: Architecture developed to meet two fundamental requirements: accommodate wide range of research designs and accommodate variable data types
evidence.verbatim_quote: We developed this architecture to meet two fundamental requirements: (1) the software had to accommodate a wide range of research designs, data schemas, and workflows, and (2) the software had to accommodate extremely variable structured, free text, multimedia, and geospatial data

evidence.evidence_text: Android client can render definition packets at runtime to instantiate arbitrary data collection methodology
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our Android client can render definition packets at runtime to instantiate an arbitrary data collection methodology (schema and workflow), save records to a datastore, and opportunistically synchronise that data with a server and from there to other mobile devices

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS is designed for offline use unlike ARK, Heurist, or Kora which require continuous server connection
evidence.verbatim_quote: It is designed for offline use, unlike most other generalised field data collection software such as ARK, Heurist, or Kora [14], which all require a continuous connection to a server

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS includes features not found in ODK: nuanced entity relationships, bi-directional sync, append-only datastore, sensor support, sophisticated export, advanced geospatial operations
evidence.verbatim_quote: It also includes features not found in ODK: more nuanced relationships between entities, bi-directional synchronisation across all devices (a feature in ODK 2.0 Tool Suite, which is in alpha release), use of an append-only datastore that provides a version history for all records, support for a wider range of external sensors and peripherals like label printers ('ODK Sensors' is in alpha release), a more sophisticated data export framework, and more advanced geospatial data operations (compared to GeoODK and its derivatives)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS has richer and more granular help and metadata capture than ODK
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS also has richer and more granular help and metadata capture

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is mature software
claims.verbatim_quote: It is mature software that has been under development since 2012

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile is open-source software that is free to use
claims.verbatim_quote: The software is free (as in speech), customisable, and extensible, accommodating arbitrary research designs

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile consists of core Java and Ruby software with customisation via XML, Beanshell, and CSS
claims.verbatim_quote: It consists of 'core' Java and Ruby software providing a platform for data capture, which can be deeply customised using 'definition packets' consisting of XML documents (data schema and UI) and Beanshell scripts (automation)

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has had five years of iterative co-development with field researchers
claims.verbatim_quote: It is purpose-built for field research with extensive community input, including five years of iterative co-development with field researchers first in archaeology, and more recently in geoscience, history, and ecology

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is differentiated from ODK by its lineage in archaeology rather than social surveys
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is most comparable to Open Data Kit (ODK) [18] and its variants, but is differentiated by its lineage. ODK was designed for social surveys, where an investigator asks questions of a interviewee. FAIMS originated in archaeology, where an investigator records observations about things in the material world

claims.claim_text: Archaeological field recording involves observations about material things, relationships, and contextualising metadata
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS originated in archaeology, where an investigator records observations about things in the material world, relationships between those observations, and metadata contextualising the collection of those observations

claims.claim_text: FAIMS deployment has been validated through published case studies
claims.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016 [8]

claims.claim_text: FAIMS DSL simplifies customisation by generating complete definition packets from a single file
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS has developed a XML-based domain specific language (DSL) to simplify customisation. Using this DSL, a single file is used to generate a complete definition packet, at the expense of some loss of independent control over each element of a customisation (data schema, UI, automation)

claims.claim_text: Projects can independently customise FAIMS without FAIMS team involvement
claims.verbatim_quote: In addition to deployments conducted by the FAIMS team, projects have independently customised FAIMS Mobile themselves using both the detailed approach of producing an entire definition packet and the simplified DSL-based method

claims.claim_text: FAIMS architecture enables runtime rendering and scripting for flexible customisation
claims.verbatim_quote: Javarosa to render native Android UI elements at runtime... Beanshell to provide runtime scripting via calls to an underlying Java API

claims.claim_text: FAIMS data schemas are definable at runtime using attribute-key-value datastore
claims.verbatim_quote: Sqlite3 to store an attribute-key-value datastore (with data schemas definable at runtime)

claims.claim_text: FAIMS provides complete version histories through append-only datastore
claims.verbatim_quote: An append-only datastore providing a full revision history, including the ability to review and reverse changes to records selectively

claims.claim_text: FAIMS provides mobile GIS capabilities for field research
claims.verbatim_quote: Mobile GIS supporting raster and vector data, layer management, legacy data visualisation, and point, line, and polygon creation and editing

claims.claim_text: FAIMS server can be hosted online or on modest hardware in the field
claims.verbatim_quote: A Ruby on Rails/Apache stack to provide a server for synchronisation, version review, user management, and similar tasks, which can be hosted online or on modest hardware in the field

claims.claim_text: Quality assurance is important for academic software and often neglected
claims.verbatim_quote: Five years of deployment experience revealed the importance of quality assurance, something too often neglected in academic software

claims.claim_text: Each FAIMS customisation and deployment is a miniature software development project requiring QA
claims.verbatim_quote: Each customisation and deployment is, indeed, a miniature software development project [8]. Due to the need for significant QA per deployment, FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has seen good uptake since public release
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the transition to digital recording during fieldwork represents a significant socio-technical change, FAIMS Mobile has seen good uptake

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times with 29 confirmed field deployments
claims.verbatim_quote: Since our first public release in 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times (by our team or independently), with 29 confirmed field deployments, nine of which included multiple field seasons

claims.claim_text: FAIMS has substantial user base with approximately 300 users and 20,000 hours of usage
claims.verbatim_quote: approximately 300 users have logged over 20,000 h employing the software

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is used across multiple disciplines including archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history
claims.verbatim_quote: employing the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research

claims.claim_text: Most FAIMS uptake has been at large, multi-year projects still early in their lifecycle
claims.verbatim_quote: Most uptake has been at large, multi-year projects that are still early in their lifecycle, so FAIMS-related publications to date have focused on the software itself or the transition from paper-based to digital workflows

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is expanding into community heritage and citizen science applications
claims.verbatim_quote: A 2016–2018 New South Wales Research Attraction and Acceleration Program award is funding deployments at additional projects, including community heritage and citizen science applications

claims.claim_text: FAIMS enables rapid prototyping with well-scoped systems achievable in one to two developer-days
claims.verbatim_quote: An experienced developer can rapidly prototype a recording system if data and workflow models are available (well-scoped systems of moderate complexity can be prototyped in one to two developer-days)

claims.claim_text: Users benefit from increased efficiency of fieldwork when using FAIMS
claims.verbatim_quote: Three case studies involving archaeological deployments [8] showed that users benefited from the increased efficiency of fieldwork

claims.claim_text: Time saved by avoiding digitisation more than offsets FAIMS implementation time
claims.verbatim_quote: The time saved by avoiding digitisation and data cleaning more than offset the time required to implement FAIMS, resulting in more data collected during fieldwork of a given duration

claims.claim_text: Born-digital data avoids problems with delayed digitisation and lost context
claims.verbatim_quote: Born-digital data avoided problems with delayed digitisation, which often occurred long after field recording when the context of the record had been forgotten, or the person who made the record was no longer available

claims.claim_text: FAIMS produces more complete, consistent, and granular data than paper-based recording
claims.verbatim_quote: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data

claims.claim_text: FAIMS enables faster information exchange between excavators and specialists
claims.verbatim_quote: They noted that information could be exchanged more quickly between excavators and specialists, which in one case improved 'post-excavation reconstruction of the site' and facilitated the evaluation of patterns for meaning in another

claims.claim_text: Transition to digital requires comprehensive reviews of field practice making implicit knowledge explicit
claims.verbatim_quote: They also observed that the process of moving from paper to digital required comprehensive reviews of field practice, during which knowledge implicit in existing systems became explicit, and data was modelled more carefully

claims.claim_text: Researchers gain software development familiarity through FAIMS implementation
claims.verbatim_quote: By participating in a 'miniature software development project', researchers gained familiarity with the strengths, limits, and demands of software, especially the need for extensive testing

claims.claim_text: Digital transition reallocates time from end of project (digitisation) to beginning (development)
claims.verbatim_quote: The greatest challenge posed by the transition from paper has been the reallocation of time from the end of a project (digitisation) to the beginning (data modelling, development, and testing), even if an overall time-savings is realised

claims.claim_text: URI embedding in controlled vocabularies connects data to linked open data sources
claims.verbatim_quote: URIs can be embedded in controlled vocabularies and other elements [17], connecting them to linked open data sources

claims.claim_text: Localisation enables translation of local terminology to standard vocabulary
claims.verbatim_quote: Localisation can be used to 'translate' a local language of practice to a standard vocabulary

claims.claim_text: Customisable export formats data for existing services, standards, and repositories
claims.verbatim_quote: Customisable data export can format data for existing services or standards

claims.claim_text: FAIMS architecture separates core software from definition packets for easier modification and reuse
claims.verbatim_quote: This distinction between the 'core' client and the definition packet resembles the one between a web browser and a website. A browser contains many sophisticated engines for rendering the page, its interactivity, and its styling, but does not have content

claims.claim_text: FAIMS architecture was designed to accommodate wide range of research designs and variable data types
claims.verbatim_quote: We developed this architecture to meet two fundamental requirements: (1) the software had to accommodate a wide range of research designs, data schemas, and workflows, and (2) the software had to accommodate extremely variable structured, free text, multimedia, and geospatial data

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Android client can render definition packets at runtime to instantiate arbitrary data collection methodology
claims.verbatim_quote: Our Android client can render definition packets at runtime to instantiate an arbitrary data collection methodology (schema and workflow), save records to a datastore, and opportunistically synchronise that data with a server

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is designed for offline use unlike other generalised field data collection software
claims.verbatim_quote: It is designed for offline use, unlike most other generalised field data collection software such as ARK, Heurist, or Kora [14], which all require a continuous connection to a server

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is more customisable with more fieldwork-specific features than ODK but customisation is more entailed
claims.verbatim_quote: In short, FAIMS is more customisable and has more fieldwork-specific features than ODK, but as a result customisation is more entailed

claims.claim_text: FAIMS makes digital recording more feasible and less costly for researchers
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile makes digital recording a more feasible and less costly option for researchers

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile offers an unparalleled range of features to support fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile offers an unparallelled range of features to support fieldwork, including collection of structured, free-text, multimedia, and geospatial data, deep customisability, mobile GIS, use of internal and external sensors, offline capability with opportunistic synchronisation using either an online or local server, full record version histories, multilingual support, certainties and annotations attached to individual fields, and rich contextual help

claims.claim_text: FAIMS improves transparency and reproducibility through comprehensive datasets mapped to vocabularies
claims.verbatim_quote: It also promotes synthetic research and improves transparency and reproducibility through the production of comprehensive datasets that can be mapped to vocabularies or ontologies as they are created

claims.claim_text: FAIMS features improve data compatibility across projects, facilitating large-scale field research
claims.verbatim_quote: Together, these features improve data compatibility across projects, facilitating large-scale field research

claims.claim_text: FAIMS can support socio-technical transition from paper to digital in field research and facilitate production of comprehensive, compatible datasets
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is community-driven, customisable, extensible software that can support the socio-technical transition from paper to digital in field research disciplines and facilitate the production of comprehensive, compatible datasets to improve synthetic research, transparency, and reproducibility

claims.claim_text: Field research disciplines often lack transparency and reproducibility
claims.verbatim_quote: Field research disciplines, however, often lack transparency and reproducibility, compromising the integrity of research results [1]

claims.claim_text: Field data is often collected using ad-hoc mix of hard copy, data fragments, and bespoke databases
claims.verbatim_quote: Field data is often collected using an ad-hoc mix of hard copy, data fragments in various formats, and bespoke databases [2–5]

claims.claim_text: Digital datasets are often highly variable, of poor quality, and incompatible, inhibiting reuse and aggregation
claims.verbatim_quote: Digital datasets are often highly variable, of poor quality, and incompatible. Deficiencies like these inhibit reuse of primary data and the aggregation of datasets from multiple studies for large-scale research [4,7,1]

claims.claim_text: Insufficient attention has been paid to developing software specifically for digital field data collection
claims.verbatim_quote: Insufficient attention has been paid to the development of software specifically designed for digital data collection during field research

claims.claim_text: Bespoke software is expensive to build and maintain, beyond reach of most projects
claims.verbatim_quote: Bespoke software is expensive to build and maintain, placing it beyond the reach of all but the best-funded projects and organisations

claims.claim_text: Repurposed software requires extensive customisation and lacks critical features for field research
claims.verbatim_quote: Repurposed software requires field researchers to make do with applications designed for other contexts, which lack critical features but still require extensive customisation

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is generalised software combining field research features with customisability for cross-disciplinary appeal
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile, conversely, is 'generalised' software which combines features required for field research with sufficient customisability to allow its use across disciplines, appealing to a large enough user base to support its development and have a meaningful impact on research

claims.claim_text: Field research represents only fraction of market for software and is unlikely to drive consumer/business software development
claims.verbatim_quote: Such research represents only a fraction of the market for consumer or business software, and is unlikely to drive its development—whereas it is the sole focus of FAIMS

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is community-driven; user-requested features can be implemented within resource constraints
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, FAIMS Mobile is community driven; if current or potential users request new features, they can be implemented (within resource constraints)

claims.claim_text: Comprehensive rather than selective datasets can be created and exported for publication
claims.verbatim_quote: Perhaps most importantly, comprehensive, rather than selective, datasets can be created and exported for publication, improving transparency and reproducibility

claims.claim_text: FAIMS allows efficient field data collection, dramatically reducing or eliminating manual digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS allows the efficient collection of field data, dramatically reducing or eliminating manual digitisation

claims.claim_text: Near-real-time data availability provides immediate error detection especially with validation
claims.verbatim_quote: Near-real-time availability of data from multiple devices for review also provides immediate error detection (especially when combined with validation)

claims.claim_text: FAIMS customisation is less expensive than bespoke mobile applications
claims.verbatim_quote: Customisation of FAIMS Mobile is therefore less expensive than production of bespoke mobile applications, and competitive with deploying the suite of generic tools field research requires

claims.claim_text: FAIMS offers better integration of data types and requires fewer compromises than generic tools
claims.verbatim_quote: At the same time, FAIMS offers better integration of different data types and requires fewer compromises on the part of the researcher compared to generic tools

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is easier to redeploy than customised suites of generic tools, allowing practices to be shared
claims.verbatim_quote: Since FAIMS is also easier to redeploy than customised suites of generic tools, it allows practices and innovations to be readily shared

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: General-purpose software tools are inherently inadequate for field research because they were designed for different contexts with different requirements
trigger_text: Insufficient attention has been paid to the development of software specifically designed for digital data collection during field research
Repurposed software requires field researchers to make do with applications designed for other contexts, which lack critical features but still require extensive customisation
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors assume that context-specific design is necessary for effective software, implying that general-purpose tools cannot adequately serve field research needs regardless of how they are configured

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: A sufficiently large user base is necessary to justify and sustain software development investment
trigger_text: appealing to a large enough user base to support its development and have a meaningful impact on research

individual 'data loggers' tied to a particular methodologies (even if extensible) and built as separate mobile applications would not appeal to a large enough audience to warrant the investment required
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors justify their generalised approach based on economic sustainability, assuming that niche tools cannot be sustainably developed for small user communities

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Runtime customisation is superior to compile-time customisation for field research software because it enables non-developers to adapt systems
trigger_text: Our Android client can render definition packets at runtime to instantiate an arbitrary data collection methodology
This distinction between the 'core' client and the definition packet resembles the one between a web browser and a website
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The browser/website analogy implies that separating platform from content enables flexibility, but this assumes users can create definition packets, which itself requires technical skill

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Digital field recording is inherently superior to paper-based recording for research quality
trigger_text: Born-digital data avoided problems with delayed digitisation
Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data
FAIMS Mobile is community-driven, customisable, extensible software that can support the socio-technical transition from paper to digital
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper frames digital recording as an advancement over paper without acknowledging potential trade-offs such as battery dependency, device failure in remote locations, or reduced tactile engagement with material

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Offline capability is essential for field research because network connectivity is unreliable in field contexts
trigger_text: It is designed for offline use, unlike most other generalised field data collection software such as ARK, Heurist, or Kora [14], which all require a continuous connection to a server
Opportunistic synchronisation whenever a connection is available, allowing devices to work in network-degraded environments or offline for extended periods of time
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The emphasis on offline capability assumes that typical field research occurs in network-degraded environments, though this varies by discipline and location

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Open-source licensing and community governance lead to better software for academic users than proprietary alternatives
trigger_text: The software is free (as in speech), customisable, and extensible, accommodating arbitrary research designs
FAIMS Mobile is community driven; if current or potential users request new features, they can be implemented
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors assume that open-source development model produces better outcomes for academic users, though this depends on sustained developer commitment and community engagement

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Standardised vocabularies and ontology linkage improve data quality and enable cross-project synthesis
trigger_text: URIs can be embedded in controlled vocabularies and other elements [17], connecting them to linked open data sources
Localisation can be used to 'translate' a local language of practice to a standard vocabulary
Together, these features improve data compatibility across projects, facilitating large-scale field research
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors assume that ontology linkage inherently improves data quality, though standardisation can also flatten meaningful local variation and impose inappropriate categorisations

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Field research across disciplines shares sufficient common requirements to justify a generalised platform
trigger_text: FAIMS Mobile is designed to collect heterogeneous data of various types (structured, free text, geospatial, multimedia), and accompanying metadata, produced using arbitrary methodologies during human-mediated field research
employing the software for archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history research
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The cross-disciplinary claims assume that archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history have sufficiently similar field data collection needs to share a platform, though their epistemologies and data types differ substantially

research_designs.description: Five years of iterative co-development with field researchers across multiple disciplines (archaeology, geoscience, history, ecology). Development driven by community input with user-requested features implemented within resource constraints.
research_designs.verbatim_quote: It is purpose-built for field research with extensive community input, including five years of iterative co-development with field researchers first in archaeology, and more recently in geoscience, history, and ecology

research_designs.description: Architecture designed to meet two fundamental requirements: accommodate wide range of research designs, data schemas, and workflows; accommodate variable structured, free text, multimedia, and geospatial data. Uses core/definition packet separation analogous to browser/website distinction.
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We developed this architecture to meet two fundamental requirements: (1) the software had to accommodate a wide range of research designs, data schemas, and workflows, and (2) the software had to accommodate extremely variable structured, free text, multimedia, and geospatial data

research_designs.description: Evaluation of software impact through deployment case studies at archaeological projects. Three case studies published in Sobotkova et al. 2016 examining user benefits, efficiency gains, and data quality improvements.
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Three deployment case studies have been published in Sobotkova et al., 2016 [8]... Three case studies involving archaeological deployments [8] showed that users benefited from the increased efficiency of fieldwork

methods.description: Continuous development and refinement of software based on deployment experience and user feedback over five years. Each customisation treated as miniature software development project.
methods.verbatim_quote: Each customisation and deployment is, indeed, a miniature software development project [8]

methods.description: User-driven feature development through community requests. Users from archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history provide feedback that shapes software development priorities.
methods.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile is community driven; if current or potential users request new features, they can be implemented (within resource constraints)

methods.description: Systematic learning from field deployment experiences to inform software architecture decisions, particularly regarding quality assurance requirements.
methods.verbatim_quote: Five years of deployment experience revealed the importance of quality assurance, something too often neglected in academic software

methods.description: Android client renders XML-based definition packets at runtime to instantiate arbitrary data collection methodologies. Definition packets contain data schema, UI specification, and automation scripts.
methods.verbatim_quote: Our Android client can render definition packets at runtime to instantiate an arbitrary data collection methodology (schema and workflow), save records to a datastore, and opportunistically synchronise that data with a server
key_parameters: Definition packet components: XML (schema, UI), Beanshell (automation), CSS (styling)

methods.description: Bi-directional data synchronisation between mobile devices and server whenever network connection is available. Uses append-only data model for version history.
methods.verbatim_quote: Opportunistic synchronisation whenever a connection is available, allowing devices to work in network-degraded environments or offline for extended periods of time

methods.description: Collection of user feedback through deployment case studies. Users report on efficiency gains, data quality improvements, and challenges encountered during transition from paper to digital recording.
methods.verbatim_quote: Researchers reported more complete, consistent, and granular data... They noted that information could be exchanged more quickly between excavators and specialists
key_parameters: Topics: efficiency, data quality, workflow changes

methods.description: Implicit method for gathering software requirements through direct collaboration with field researchers. The paper references extensive community input and co-development but does not specify the methodology for requirements elicitation, prioritisation, or validation.
methods.inference_basis: Paper describes co-development outcomes but not the requirements gathering process. References to 'community input' and 'user-requested features' imply requirements gathering occurred but methodology is not documented.

methods.description: Implicit method for managing software versions and releases. The paper references specific version numbers (2.5, 2.5.20) and GitHub repositories but does not describe versioning strategy, release cycles, or backward compatibility approach.
methods.inference_basis: Version numbers and GitHub repositories indicate formal version control practices, but methodology and policies are not documented.

protocols.description: Two approaches for creating definition packets: (1) detailed approach producing complete definition packet with independent control over schema, UI, and automation; (2) simplified DSL-based approach using single XML file to generate complete definition packet.
protocols.verbatim_quote: FAIMS has developed a XML-based domain specific language (DSL) to simplify customisation. Using this DSL, a single file is used to generate a complete definition packet, at the expense of some loss of independent control over each element of a customisation (data schema, UI, automation)
steps: Gather data model and workflow requirements from researchers
Define UI layout and field types
Write Beanshell automation scripts if needed

protocols.description: Workflow for deploying customised FAIMS Mobile instances to field research projects. Includes pre-deployment testing, field setup, and ongoing support.
protocols.verbatim_quote: Since our first public release in 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been customised at least 40 times (by our team or independently), with 29 confirmed field deployments, nine of which included multiple field seasons
steps: Set up server (online or local field hardware)

protocols.description: Automated testing of customised data collection modules using Robotium framework. Unit and integration tests allow large amounts of test data to be automatically added via normal user interface.
protocols.verbatim_quote: Due to the need for significant QA per deployment, FAIMS Mobile 2.5+ supports Robotium for unit and integration tests on customised data collection modules, such that large amounts of test data can be automatically added via the normal user interface
steps: Create Robotium test scripts for customised module

protocols.description: Customisable export of field data to various formats and standards for ingest into existing geodatabases or domain-specific repositories.
protocols.verbatim_quote: Customisable data export can format data for existing services or standards (e.g., archaeological records can be exported not only as shapefiles, CSVs, or a 3NF relational database for incorporation into an existing geodatabase, but also as XML or GeoJSON for ingest into domain-specific repositories like Open Context)
steps: Map local vocabularies to standard ontologies using localisation

protocols.description: Implicit protocol for training field researchers to use FAIMS Mobile. The deployment workflow mentions 'train field users' but does not document the training curriculum, duration, materials, or assessment of competency.
steps: Unstated: training delivery format (in-person, online, materials)
protocols.inference_basis: Paper mentions that researchers 'gained familiarity with the strengths, limits, and demands of software' but training methodology is not documented.

protocols.description: Implicit protocol for selecting projects/partners for co-development and deployment. The paper references multiple disciplinary collaborations but does not explain how partner projects were identified, evaluated, or onboarded.
protocols.inference_basis: Paper describes deployments across archaeology, ecology, geoscience, and history but does not document how these disciplinary partnerships were established or selected.

sources.funder: National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources programme (NeCTAR)
New South Wales Government Research Attraction and Acceleration Program

funding.acknowledgement_text: This work was supported by the National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources programme (RT043; V005), the Australian Research Council (LE140100151), the New South Wales Government Research Attraction and Acceleration Program, Macquarie University, Flinders University, La Trobe University, Southern Cross University, the University of Queensland, the University of Sydney, UNSW Australia, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation ON Prime programme, and fees paid by our users for consultation, customisation, deployment, and support services.

machine_actionability.rationale: Software publication - no research data to deposit. Software itself is the primary output.

Code available on GitHub with clear licensing (GPLv3), version control, extensive documentation (Module Cookbook, Beanshell API, User-to-Developer guide), and multiple distribution channels (GitHub, Google Play, direct APK)

ethics_approval.rationale: Software publication describing infrastructure tool - no human subjects research

permits_and_authorizations.rationale: Software publication - no fieldwork conducted for this paper

materials.description: Getting started guide and user documentation

findable.rationale: Paper has DOI (10.1016/j.softx.2017.12.006), software available on GitHub with persistent archive link, Google Play, and project website

accessible.rationale: Open access paper (CC BY licence), open source software (GPLv3), multiple download channels, no access barriers

interoperable.rationale: Uses standard technologies (XML, SQL, GeoJSON, CSV, shapefiles), supports URI embedding for linked open data, customisable export to standard formats

reusable.rationale: GPLv3 licence permits modification and redistribution, extensive documentation provided, definition packets can be shared and reused via GitHub library

extraction_notes.pass_0_notes: Metadata extracted from 6-page software publication. This is a methodological paper describing FAIMS Mobile software. No traditional empirical research design - paper documents software architecture, features, and impact. Context flags: 📦 (infrastructure), 🔧 (tool).
extraction_notes.pass_1_notes: Liberal extraction yielded 43 evidence items, 59 claims, and 8 implicit arguments. Evidence primarily consists of software specifications, usage statistics, and user feedback. Claims are predominantly methodological arguments about software design benefits. Paper makes extensive comparative claims against ODK and other tools.
extraction_notes.pass_2_notes: Rationalization review complete. Analysed evidence and claim granularity - E020/E021 describe related but distinct aspects of deployment (customisations vs field deployments), E003/E038 serve different contexts (code metadata vs architecture description). All 43 evidence items serve distinct argumentative functions. Claims appropriately differentiated between empirical observations (C017-C028), methodological arguments (C005-C016, C029-C039), and interpretive conclusions (C040-C044). 8 implicit arguments capture key design and methodological assumptions underpinning the paper's argument structure. No consolidation required.
extraction_notes.pass_3_notes: RDMAP extraction complete. Identified 3 research designs (participatory co-development, generalised software architecture, case study evaluation), 6 methods (iterative development, community engagement, deployment-based learning, runtime rendering, opportunistic sync, user feedback), and 4 protocols (definition packet creation, field deployment, QA testing, data export). This software publication describes development methodology rather than traditional empirical research designs.
extraction_notes.pass_4_notes: Implicit RDMAP extraction complete. Added 2 implicit methods (requirements gathering M007, version control M008) and 2 implicit protocols (user training P005, partner selection P006). These capture methodological elements implied by the paper's descriptions of co-development and deployment but not explicitly documented. Key gaps include: requirements elicitation methodology, version release strategy, training curriculum, and partner project selection criteria.
extraction_notes.pass_5_notes: RDMAP rationalisation complete. Verified hierarchy: RD001→M001,M002,M003; RD002→M004,M005; RD003→M006. Protocol linkages: M001→P001,P002; M003→P003; M004→P001. Implicit elements (M007, M008, P005, P006) appropriately capture unstated methodological components. No redundancy detected. Cross-references to claims validated. Final RDMAP: 3 designs, 8 methods (6 explicit, 2 implicit), 6 protocols (4 explicit, 2 implicit).
extraction_notes.pass_6_notes: Infrastructure extraction complete. Identified 11 funding sources (NeCTAR RT043/V005, ARC LE140100151, NSW RAAP, 7 universities, CSIRO ON Prime, plus user fees). Code availability: high - multiple repositories (GitHub, Google Play, direct APK), GPLv3 licence, extensive documentation. FAIR assessment: high across all dimensions. No ethics approval or fieldwork permits required (software publication). No author ORCIDs provided in paper. Supplementary materials include video and comprehensive developer/user documentation.
extraction_notes.pass_7_notes: Cross-reference validation complete. Final counts: 43 evidence, 59 claims, 8 implicit arguments, 3 research designs, 8 methods (6 explicit, 2 implicit), 6 protocols (4 explicit, 2 implicit), 11 funding sources, 5 supplementary materials. All cross-references validated. Extraction pipeline (Pass 0-7) complete.
known_limitations: Software publication format differs from empirical research papers
Impact claims based on self-reported user feedback without independent validation
Usage statistics are aggregate without demographic breakdown
